abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Productive
            Safety Nets Project (PSNP) Project for Ethiopia was rated
            satisfactory, the risk to the development outcome was
            substantial, and the performance of the Bank and Borrower
            was also rated as satisfactory. The PSNP is a flagship for
            what can be done to smooth consumption and protect the most
            vulnerable in a very low-income country. However, the
            Ethiopian experience is highly contextualized upon the
            country's twenty year experience with significant
            amounts of humanitarian relief assistance. In such an
            environment, the main issue is to reduce distortions and
            dependency while shifting from emergency food aid to a
            greater developmental impact. Nonetheless, several lessons
            from Ethiopia may be relevant to other countries, divided
            into general design, operational and donor coordination
            aspects: (a) the extensive analytical underpinning and
            technical inputs, both at the design stage and during
            implementation, were critical to program success. The bold
            policy vision of the PSNP had to be built on a sound and
            shared understanding of the strengths and weaknesses of the
            present system and clarity on the nature of the problem to
            be addressed. Complex and high risk reforms such as those
            embodied in this operation are much more likely to succeed
            if this foundation is present; and (b) the use of existing
            Government channels and institutional structures builds
            ownership but presents capacity issues that need to be
            addressed. Weaknesses, gaps, and capacity constraints in the
            overall functioning of government structures need to be
            strategically addressed upfront. Relying on broad civil
            service reforms, like changes in salaries and hiring and
            firing rules, will not ease constraints in the short-term.
            With the caveat that very few countries besides Ethiopia
            have the type of existing bureaucratic structure around
            massive delivery of food aid upon which to piggyback a
            safety net program.
